The Radio Shack Dune Warrior sends a binary encoded pulse, where 0's seem to be
represented as pulses of length 127 us followed by 127 us of silence and 1's
represented as pulses of length 200 us followed by 200 us of silence. Each
signal starts with a synchronization burst of 500 us and 500 us of silence,
followed by 22 bit pulses.

Observed command codes:
straight, idle
00000010 10000111 001000

straight, increasing throttle from idle to full forward
00000010 10010111 000000
00000010 10100111 000000
00000010 10110111 001000
00000010 11000111 000000
00000010 11010111 001000
00000010 11100111 001000
00000010 11110111 000000

straight to right, idle
00010010 10000111 000000
00110010 10000111 001000
01010010 10000111 001000
01100010 10000111 001000
10000010 10000111 000000
10010010 10000111 001000
10100010 10000111 001000
10110010 10000111 000000
11000010 10000111 001000
11010010 10000111 000000
11100010 10000111 000000
11110010 10000111 001000
00010011 10000111 001000
00110011 10000111 000000
00100011 10000111 001000
00110011 10000111 000000
01010011 10000111 000000
01000011 10000111 001000
01010011 10000111 000000
01100011 10000111 000000
01110011 10000111 001000
10000011 10000111 001000
10010011 10000111 000000
10100011 10000111 000000
10110011 10000111 001000
11000011 10000111 000000
11010011 10000111 001000
11110011 10000111 000000

straight to left, idle
11100001 10000111 000000
11000001 10000111 001000
10110001 10000111 000000
10100001 10000111 001000
10010001 10000111 001000
10000001 10000111 000000
01110001 10000111 000000
01100001 10000111 001000
01010001 10000111 001000
01000001 10000111 000000
00110001 10000111 000000
00100001 10000111 000000
00010001 10000111 000000
00000001 10000111 001000
11110000 10000111 000000
11100000 10000111 001000
11010000 10000111 001000
11000000 10000111 001000
10110000 10000111 001000
10100000 10000111 001000
10010000 10000111 000000
10000000 10000111 001000
01110000 10000111 001000
01100000 10000111 000000
01010000 10000111 000000
01000000 10000111 001000
00100000 10000111 001000

Bits 7-8 + bits 1-4 form a 6-bit command for steering. Larger values are used
for turning right, while smaller values are for turning left. The value is
offset by 32, so 32 is centered while 63 is full right and 0 is full left. It
should be noted that we never observed full left being sent, only 2.

Bits 9-13 control the throttle. Larger values are used for forward and smaller
for reverse. The value is offset by 16, so 16 is idle.

Bit 19 is an even parity bit.

Bits 5-6, 17-18, and 20-22 are constant 0. Bits 14-16 are constant 1.
